dlgPart.npc_text:
Over the course of his life, Varro has developed a pragmatic observation that life is all about survival and making it to the next day. Principles and other questionable qualities were dead weight that would get you killed and were no use to you once you’re dead.
Thus, loyalties and honor were nothing but summer flowers – pretty when it’s warm but quickly forgotten when the harsher seasons come. Such a season did come recently, putting an untimely end to a score of the Boatmen and Varro’s career as the guildmaster and presenting him with new opportunities.
“Welcome to Ganezzar, <master/mistress> <charname>,” smiles Varro. “What can I do for you?”

dlgAnsw.text: “Master Athanasius wants to retain your services.”

dlgPart.npc_text: “I’m in the business of rooting out heresy these days,” says Varro with a smile. “Of course, if the man in question is a heretic...” He looks at you questioningly.
“Faelan,” Varro says thoughtfully. “Correct me if I’m wrong, but isn’t he Lord Meru’s most loyal servant?”

dlgAnsw.text: “It occurred to me that you may want to become the most loyal servant yourself. Then Faelan would be in your way.”
“Most loyal servants are as prone to mortality as disloyal ones. Maybe even more so.”

dlgPart.npc_text:
“He would, wouldn’t he? Well, as much as I appreciate your concerns about my social status, I’m afraid I’ll have to decline.
“You see, I’ve entered into Lord Meru’s service very recently and I feel that it would be too soon to start killing people who happened to be in my way.”

dlgAnsw.text: [intelligence][streetwise]“In other words, you think you’ll be blamed for it.”
[streetwise]“Well, take your time. I’m sure that Faelan will wait until you’re good and ready before taking you out.”

dlgPart.npc_text: “Indeed,” says Varro, pursing his lips. “Nothing is more dangerous to one’s health than unwavering loyalty.”

“I can’t help you,” says Varro, shaking his head.
“You see, I’ve entered into Lord Meru’s service very recently and I feel that it would be too soon to start killing people who happened to be in my way.”

dlgAnsw.text: [intelligence][streetwise]“In other words, you think you’ll be blamed for it.”
[streetwise]“Well, take your time. I’m sure that Faelan will wait until you’re good and ready before taking you out.”

dlgPart.npc_text: “I will *if* I decide to do it and we both know that Athanasius will pay it. So no, it’s not about money. Not yet, at least.”

dlgAnsw.text: [intelligence][streetwise]“In other words, you think you’ll be blamed for it.”
[streetwise]“Well, take your time. I’m sure that Faelan will wait until you’re good and ready before taking you out.”

dlgPart.npc_text: “Of course I will be blamed for it, considering what happened to my guild. Meru will think that I’m getting even and I’ll be dead before I can blink.”

dlgAnsw.text: “Can you pin it on someone else? Robbery gone wrong? Happens all the time, no?”

dlgPart.npc_text: Varro shrugs. “Risky. Meru's men will talk to Glabrio and know right away that he had nothing to do with it.”

dlgAnsw.text: [intelligence success]“Unless, of course, he did have something to do with it.”
[streetwise]“Well, take your time. I’m sure that Faelan will wait until you’re good and ready before taking you out.”

dlgPart.npc_text: [failure]“I admire your persistence, <charname>, but if you want him dead so badly, you'll have to do it yourself. Faelan spends his nights in the library, alone. Probably thinks he's invulnerable because he has that one trick up his sleeve.”
[success]“What do you mean?” asks Varro, developing a sudden interest in this conversation.

dlgAnsw.text: [persuasion][streetwise]“What would you do if you were in his place? You’d kill your rival before he gets too comfortable and too close to Meru.”

dlgPart.npc_text: [success]“Damned if you do, damned if you don’t, eh? If I kill him now – assuming he can be killed to begin with – Meru will know it was me and have me killed. If I wait...”

dlgAnsw.text: “Can you pin it on someone else? Robbery gone wrong? Happens all the time, no?”

dlgPart.npc_text: [failure]“Am I supposed to believe that? No offense, <charname>.”

dlgAnsw.text: “Can you pin it on someone else? Robbery gone wrong? Happens all the time, no?”

[persuasion][trading]“You should. We’ll back you up because we hope that you’ll do the same when the time comes. Our future is with House Crassus now, but we’re late to the party. So, either we work together and ally against common enemies or we stand alone and watch as our enemies gain strength.”

dlgPart.npc_text: [success]“They say you always keep your word, so I suppose that’s good enough for me. Alright. I’ll do it but I’ll need some time to put together a crew. You’ll know when it’s done.”
[success]“Alright. I’ll do it but I’ll need some time to put together a crew. You’ll know when it’s done.”
“What are you talking about?”

dlgAnsw.text: “If you can’t kill Faelan yourself get someone else to do it for you. We’ll treat it as your kill and pay you as agreed.”

dlgPart.npc_text: “And why would Glabrio want to do it? He’s dumb but not that dumb.”

dlgAnsw.text: [persuasion][streetwise]“Tell him that as the brand new Inquisitor of House Crassus, you’ve learned that Faelan is planning to clean up the city, starting with Glabrio and his miscreants. Tell him he asked for your help in this endeavor, but you just had to warn your old pal Glabrio.”

dlgPart.npc_text: [success]“Alright. I'll talk to Glabrio, but it will take some time. You’ll know when it’s done.”
END - failed
END - success
“What can I do for you, <master/mistress> <charname>?”

dlgAnsw.text: “Master Athanasius wants to retain your services.”

dlgPart.npc_text: END - visit the Boatmen
“You’ve been asking questions about the Boatmen. Why?” asks Varro, playing with a dagger.

“How thoughtful of her,” smiles Varro. The smile is menacing. In fact, you aren’t sure that Varro can smile or do anything in a non-menacing way. Probably wore this mask for so long, he forgot who he was beneath it.
“So,” he gives you a long, hard look as if deciding what to do with you, “seeing that I don’t need any avenging – not at the moment, at least, how about we find a more suitable use for your talents?”

“Are you?” smiles Varro. The smile is menacing. In fact, you aren’t sure that Varro can smile or do anything in a non-menacing way. Probably wore this mask for so long, he forgot who he was beneath it.
“How do I know Darista didn't send you?”

“Never did like that bitch. So,” he gives you a long, hard look as if deciding what to do with you, “seeing that I don’t have to worry about Darista, how about we find a suitable use for your talents?”
“Short version? They failed to embrace the change and died for their sins.”
[charisma failure]“The long version we don’t have time for.”

[charisma success]“It happened too fast,” says Varro, looking away. “The mob rushes us, killed those closest to the door first – tore them apart. The others tried to fight but it was futile. I dropped on my knees and started praying.”

“Praying as loudly as I could so that these assholes can see and hear me praying. They thought it was a miracle and took me to Meru to repent my sins. He told me that I work for him now and considering the alternative, I didn’t feel like arguing.”

dlgAnsw.text: “You saved your ass while your brethren fought and died.”

dlgPart.npc_text: “Everyone works for someone. Darista works for Gaelius. Neleos did Antidas’ bidding. Given a choice, I would have stayed away from politics, but...” He shrugs.

dlgAnsw.text: “What exactly do you do for him?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “Everyone works for someone. Darista worked for Gaelius. Neleos did Antidas’ bidding. Given a choice, I would have stayed away from politics, but...” He shrugs.

dlgAnsw.text: “What exactly do you do for him?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “I’m in the business of rooting out heresy these days,” says Varro with a smile. “Of course, there are more pressing matters at the moment.”
“You’re an assassin and I’m still a guildmaster. You can work for me unless you’d rather go back to Darista.”
“You’re an assassin and I’m still a guildmaster. You can work for me unless you’d rather go back to Maadoran.”

“You wanted to know what happened to the Boatmen? Now you know. I don’t kill people for asking questions, *but* should you choose to come back, I’ll assume that you’re here to be on business and act accordingly. Are we clear?”
END
“Alright,” nods Varro, seemingly pleased with your decision. “Welcome to the guild.”

dlgAnsw.text: “How many people are in the guild?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “Right now? You and me. In the near future? Might be down to one again because we have a lot of hard work to do and there are only two of us.”
“I like your attitude,” smiles Varro. “Here is the situation. The town’s under siege as I’m sure you’ve noticed. Our task’s two-fold: break the siege and protect Meru. He dies, it’s all over.”

dlgAnsw.text: “Break the siege? The two of us?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “You’ve ever heard of Darius? A warlord, back in the day. He gathered a large army and laid siege to Ganezzar. He would have taken it too but the Boatmen got to him first. I would lie if I tell you that it was a two-man team, but you never know. Maybe it was.”

“Well, you talked to the Legatus – don’t look surprised, nobody gets in without me knowing how they got in. What did he ask? Keep an eye out, kill Meru if you see him strolling down the street? No matter. Point is, you can easily get in. It’s getting out that’s going to be a problem, but that’s where I come in.”
“One problem at a time, alright? If it fails, then we deal with it, assuming we’re still alive. If not, it’s going to be someone else’s problem.”
“If the army fails to take the city by force, they will send assassins. The only reason they haven’t done it yet is because they don’t have any local assets left.”
“First, we’re going to pay the Aurelian Legatus a visit. How many guards does he have?”
“Then here is plan A: you go in, kill all three, leave the tent and disappear without a trace, while I cover your ass in case you fail to kill them before they raise the alarm.”

dlgAnsw.text: “Why is it always me who has to go in first?”
“And if they do raise alarm, then what?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “I’ll be right there, wearing one of those shiny uniforms and ready to do some fireworks. If it does go south, put on their armor – you’ll never get out of the camp without it.”

dlgAnsw.text: “Why is it always me who has to go in first?”
“I need some time to prepare.” Leave.

dlgPart.npc_text: “Because the legatus knows you and thinks that you’re on his side. He doesn’t know me, so he’ll be on guard and almost impossible to catch unawares.”

dlgAnsw.text: “And if they do raise alarm, then what?”
“I need some time to prepare.” Leave.

dlgPart.npc_text: “In my experience, nothing works as well or as fast as a blade through the heart, but it’s your show.”

dlgAnsw.text: “Why is it always me who has to go in first?”
“And if they do raise alarm, then what?”
“I need some time to prepare.” Leave.

dlgPart.npc_text: END - AG7 need time
"So are you in or not?"
“My favourite disciple... Ready for some work?”

"Let me show you a good way to surprise your mark first..."
Like a street magician Varro conjures his daggers out of the bracers and belt, turning even the most harmless gestures into potentially lethal attacks. Hopefully you learned something.
END - start AG7
END - start AG8
“The Boatmen are here, but that’s not our biggest problem at the moment. Faelan turned. He’s the one who helped them get inside.”
“Meru’s magus. If he looks you in the eyes, you’re as good as dead, so you’d have to fight him blind.”
“To say the least. If he looks you in the eyes, you’re as good as dead, so you’d have to fight him blind.”

“I’ll keep Meru safe from the Boatmen. If he dies, it’s over.
“Don’t worry. Faelan is a one trick pony. If you keep your eyes closed, there is no way he can beat you. He is a courtier not a fighter.”

dlgAnsw.text: “What's the best way to do it?”
“I need some time to prepare.” Leave.
“What about the Aurelians? We killed the Legatus but they’re still sitting out there.”

dlgPart.npc_text:
“He stays up late in his quarters here, working on Gods know what. He must be stopped.
“I'll make sure that you won't be disturbed.”

dlgAnsw.text: “Alright.” Wait after dark and visit Faelan the Thrice-Blessed.
“I need some time to prepare.” Leave.

dlgPart.npc_text:
“Did you expect them to pack up and leave? It’s going to be a long dance.
“We sent them a message, saying that we aren’t afraid and can kill anyone we damn please. House Aurelian will send another Legatus, but the replacement will be jumpy and paranoid, afraid of his own shadows, which isn’t a good quality. We won’t get to him but we won’t have to.
“Now they sent the Boatmen to deliver a message of their own. We stop them, we’re way ahead in the game, but first, let’s take care of Faelan.”

dlgAnsw.text: “What's the best way to do it?”
“I need some time to prepare.” Leave.

dlgPart.npc_text: END - AG8 need time
“Well done. Did anyone see you?”

dlgAnsw.text: “I don't think so. What about the Boatmen?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “They didn't make their move yet. Why don't you pay them a visit? See what they are up to. They're in the old guild building. Probably think it's the last place anyone will look for them.”

“They could have done the same,” shrugs Varro. “Some men are eager to die for their beliefs, no matter how misguided. Others – not so much.
“The zealots kill each other in Lowtown because they disagree on the matters of faith they all share. Don’t expect me to applaud their convictions.”

“There is nothing honorable about being hacked to pieces by the zealots. Nothing at all.
“They say that Darista left Jellal and his ‘lions’ to die after Asmara was taken. She spent years fighting with them side by side but the moment she saw the writing on the wall, she was gone. Does it make her dishonorable or merely pragmatic?”
“It's exactly the same. She didn't want to die with her brethren. Neither did I. Her brethren were free to follow her lead. They didn't. What else is there to say?”

“The zealots are already doing it but their way breeds chaos. Meru wants to restore order but without taking the bone away from his dogs.
“So we’ll fight heresy to keep the zealots happy, but we’ll do it in an organized and proper way, starting with the most active zealots.”

“They were allowed to believe that they run Lowtown. When they are dragged away, kicking and screaming, those who take their places will know that certain lines must never be crossed and that nobody is above the law, be it the law of Gods or mere men.”

“Until the Gods decide to grace us with their presence and take it from there, it’s pretty much the same thing. Meru sets the general direction; we interpret it to the best of our humble abilities. If mistakes are made, well, we’re only human, aren’t we?”

dlgAnsw.text: “Does Meru know that you aren’t a believer?”

dlgPart.npc_text:
“Our noble brother lives in a world of his own. We mustn’t trouble him with insignificant details.
“Sometimes he almost acts like a lord I remember. He has enough pious men he could have put in charge of his inquisition. Yet he put me in charge. Is it because he bought my epiphany or because of my experience? Even after all this time, I still don’t know the answer to this question.”
“I wouldn’t say it loud. It’s the very heresy we want to discourage.”
